transcript.text: In our previous presentation, we understood what is Big O notation and with the help of an example, we learned how Big O notation is helpful. It helps in describing the performance of an algorithm with respect to the input size. In other words, it tells the growth rate of an algorithm. We took an example of linear search. In the last lecture, we observed that the growth rate of linear search is linear with respect to the input size. This means the growth rate of linear search is Big O of n and this means as the size of the input increases, the running time of linear search increases with the same rate. That's why the growth is linear. Now in this lecture, we will try to describe the growth rate of binary search and that too using the Big O notation. So, the title of this lecture is Big O notation and Binary Search. Let's get started with this lecture and let's see what are the topics. The first topic of this lecture is Big O notation and Binary Search. The second topic is growth rate of binary search and the third topic is growth rate comparison of linear search and binary search. Let's get started with the first topic which is Big O notation and Binary Search. In case of linear search, we know that we compare each element of the list with the key which we want to find. But in case of binary search, we do not do this. In binary search, every time half of the list is eliminated, this means we do not compare each element of the list with the key. Instead, we every time compare the middle of the list with the key. Therefore, the number of comparisons in case of binary search is less than that of the linear search. Let's draw the table of number of items and number of comparisons in case of binary search. Let's say that the number of items is 10. In binary search, the number of comparisons will be 4. If we have 100 items, then the number of comparisons will be 7. If we have 1 billion items, then the number of comparisons will be just 30. What if we have n items? What will be the number of comparisons? Is it n? No. We can observe that the number of items is not directly proportional to number of comparisons. If we have 10 items, then the number of comparisons is 4. If we have 100 items, then the number of comparisons is 7. If we have 1 billion items, then the number of comparisons is 30. What about n? What will be the number of comparisons in this case? This is not as straightforward as linear search. In order to determine the number of comparisons, here if we have n items, then we need to do some calculation. We know that in binary search, every time we divide the list by half, this means every time half of the list is eliminated. Let's take 100 items. We know in the second stage, we will be left with 50 items. After this, we will be left with 25 items. Then we will be left with 12 items. Then 6 items. Then 3 items. And finally, 1 item. And the number of comparisons will be 7. The number of comparisons is equal to the number of boxes we see here. There are 7 boxes. Therefore, the number of comparisons is 7. So, when we have 100 items, number of comparisons will be maximum to maximum 7. Now, what if we take n items? In the second stage, we will be left with n by 2 items. Just like in case of 100 items, we will be left with 50 items in the second stage. Similarly, when we have n items, in the second stage, we will be left with n by 2 items. We need to divide the list by half. Or in other words, we will be left with half of the list, which is n by 2. What happens in the third stage? We will be left with n by 2 items. Because again, we need to divide the list by half. In the fourth stage, we will be left with n by 2 to the power 3 items. And this will continue up to n by 2 to the power of k. This we know is equal to 1 because at the end, we will be left with 1 item. So, n by 2 to the power k items is equal to 1. How many boxes do we have here? We want to determine the number of comparisons or the number of operations bind research takes. In order to know this, we need to know how many boxes we have here. Here, we have n by 2 to the power 0 items. Here, we have n by 2 to the power 1 items. Here, we have n by 2 to the power 2 items and so on. Up to n by 2 to the power k items. This means we have a total of k plus 1 boxes. k boxes from here to here and 1 extra box here. So, a total of k plus 1 boxes. We are assuming k is some constant. But we don't know its value yet. Up to this point, we know we have k plus 1 boxes. And k plus 1 boxes means we need k plus 1 comparisons in case of bind research when we have n items. So, there are k plus 1 comparisons. To simplify the calculation, let us assume that we just need k comparisons. In place of k plus 1, now we need k comparisons. This is just for the simplification of the calculation. So, now we want to know the value of k because we eventually want to know how many comparisons bind research takes in case of n items. How do we find the value of k? We know n by 2 to the power k is equal to 1. We just need to solve this equality. Let's do this. n by 2 to the power k is equal to 1. This implies n is equal to 2 to the power k or 2 to the power k is equal to n. We just need to multiply 2 to the power k on both sides. And we will get 2 to the power k equal to n. Now, let's apply log on both sides. I am assuming that you already know the basics of logarithm. By applying log on both sides, we will get log 2 to the power k base 2 equal to log n base 2. I am applying log base 2 on both sides here. That is why we are getting log 2 to the power k base 2 here in the left hand side and log n base 2 on the right hand side of the equality. Now, let's solve this. Log 2 to the power k base 2 is k. So, this implies k is equal to log n base 2. And what is k? k represents the number of comparisons or the number of operations. So, the number of comparisons is log n base 2. And hence, the running time of this algorithm, which is binary search, is big O of log n. I mentioned earlier that big O notation tells the running time as the number of operations. This log n represents the number of operations. And this is not the precise value. We know we need k plus 1 comparisons. So, this must be log n base 2 plus 1. But we are not considering that plus 1 because, again, we are just estimating the running time. We do not have to worry about the constants. Hence, we can say running time is big O of log n. Even I haven't mentioned base 2 here. This is also not important. What is important is that the growth rate of binary search is logarithmic. This means as the size of the input increases, the number of operations increases logarithmically. So, the growth rate is logarithmic. I hope this concept is clear. So, running time of binary search is big O of log n. These many operations binary search takes to come to the conclusion whether the key is available in the list of n items or not. So, in case of n items, the running time is big O of log n. So, this means we can replace question mark by log n. And hence, the running time is big O of log n. So, with this, we calculated the growth rate of binary search.
